M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Now comes Plaintiff, Rachel Thompson, residing at [Your Current Address], who files this Complaint for Modification of Custody pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and applicable case law, seeking a modification of the custody order entered by this Honorable Court on May 15, 2022.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 31, the central inquiry for custody and parenting time modifications is the best interests of the child, including the child’s educational needs.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently upheld custody modifications when a material and substantial change in circumstances affects the child’s welfare.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion does not involve a post-judgment custody modification based on a material and substantial change in circumstances; it concerns the initial divorce judgment awarding physical custody to the mother and authorizing removal of the children to Greece. The court discusses best interests and the ‘real advantage’ removal standard, not the standard for modifying an existing custody order due to changed circumstances, nor does it make any statement about Massachusetts courts ‘consistently’ upholding such modifications. Accordingly, it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not… be removed out of this commonwealth… without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently upheld custody modifications when a material and substantial change in circumstances affects the child’s welfare. See, e.g., Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) (holding that the court must focus on the child’s needs and welfare).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, with parents sharing joint physical and legal custody. The court applies a ‘best interests of the child’ standard specific to relocation, not a general ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ standard for custody modification. While the opinion emphasizes that the court must focus on the child’s best interests and welfare, it does not frame its analysis in terms of or endorse the ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ requirement referenced in the proposition, so it only partially matches the claimed use and does not truly support it as phrased.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents…shall not…be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth…without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’… ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’… From this the judge determined that it was not in the children’s best interests to be removed to Bristol.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Courts recognize that inconsistent school attendance and a child’s declining academic performance directly impact their best interests and provide grounds for modifying parenting time.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody and visitation under a general ‘best interests of the child’ standard, focusing on parental conflict, joint custody, and some issues like hygiene, but it does not mention school attendance, academic performance, or educational decline as a basis to modify parenting time. The reduction of the father’s visitation is tied to parental antagonism and incidents ‘inconsistent with the best interests of the children,’ not to inconsistent school attendance or deteriorating school performance. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific educational-based proposition claimed.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order… We do not think it would serve any useful purpose to recount portions of the evidence from which the judge could reasonably have determined that incidents inconsistent with the best interests of the children (e.g., substandard personal hygiene) occurred during certain extended periods when the husband was exercising his visitation rights under the temporary custody order.”

Hewitt v. Hewitt, 2018 Mass. App. Unpub..raw_text: Hewitt v. Hewitt, 2018 Mass. App. Unpub. LEXIS 298
Hewitt v. Hewitt, 2018 Mass. App. Unpub..proposition: The Defendant’s refusal to transport the child to tutoring, coupled with keeping her home from school without legitimate justification, frustrates the child’s right to an education and contravenes the principles outlined in Hewitt v. Hewitt, 2018 Mass. App. Unpub. LEXIS 298.

Gerry v. Gerry, 100 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (20.raw_text: Gerry v. Gerry, 100 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (2021)
Gerry v. Gerry, 100 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (20.proposition: This Court has the authority to modify the parenting schedule where a substantial interference with the child’s educational needs exists.
Gerry v. Gerry, 100 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion provided is Commonwealth v. Gonzalez Santos, a criminal case about sufficiency of the evidence for child rape and indecent assault convictions. It does not concern family law, parenting schedules, or the court’s authority to modify parenting time for educational reasons. Therefore it does not address, much less support, the proposition about modifying a parenting schedule due to interference with a child’s educational needs.
Gerry v. Gerry, 100 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (20.relevant_excerpt: "This case involves sufficiency of the evidence to support convictions of rape of a child and indecent assault and battery on a child under the age of fourteen. ... The defendant's sole argument on appeal is that the evidence was not sufficient to support his convictions."

Califano v. Califano, 74 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Califano v. Califano, 74 Mass. App. Ct. 719 (2009)
Califano v. Califano, 74 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: This Court has the authority to modify the parenting schedule where a substantial interference with the child’s educational needs exists. See Gerry v. Gerry, 100 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (2021); Califano v. Califano, 74 Mass. App. Ct. 719 (2009).
Califano v. Califano, 74 Mass. App. Ct..case_name: Russell v. City of New Bedford
Califano v. Califano, 74 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Califano v. Califano and does not involve parenting schedules, child custody, or educational needs; it concerns negligence and § 1983 claims against the city of New Bedford for demolition of buildings. Nothing in the decision addresses a court’s authority to modify a parenting schedule, let alone on the basis of interference with a child’s educational needs. Accordingly, this opinion does not support the stated family-law proposition.
Califano v. Califano, 74 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: Background. At the time the buildings were demolished in December, 1998, Mark Andrews was the record owner at the registry of deeds and on the city tax rolls. Andrews bought the property at 9-11 Penniman Street in 1996 with financing secured by a mortgage to the plaintiff. In 1997, Andrews delivered a deed in lieu of foreclosure to the plaintiff, but the plaintiff did not record the deed. The city targeted the buildings for demolition . . . .

Hunter v. Hunter, 990 N.E.2d 1091 (2013).proposition: When co-parenting proves unworkable due to one party’s noncompliance, Massachusetts law permits modification to ensure the child’s interests are prioritized.

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: In matters concerning education, the courts have discretion to designate one parent as having decision-making authority where joint legal custody is no longer feasible.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns relocation and the statutory rights of an unmarried mother as the sole legal parent before and after adjudication of paternity; it does not discuss allocation of educational decision‑making or modification of joint legal custody. The court addresses custody and visitation generally and the limits on a judge’s authority to order a parent to return to Massachusetts, not the court’s discretion to designate one parent as the sole decision-maker for education when joint legal custody is unworkable. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition claimed about educational decision-making authority.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: "After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate."
